text: So I've recently come out with a couple videos talking about how we're getting $4,000 a week in production on this vegetable farm. And in this video I want to explain a little bit about our yields that we're harvesting every week to get to that $4,000. I think that'll kind of clear up any confusion you get from that because just the number could mean a lot of different things. But I want to really explain how much food we're really producing on a half an acre of land, which is a tiny amount of land. You know, you can do a half an acre of production in Chicago, downtown, in the city of Chicago. You know, that's not a lot of land. So I'm going to go over that today. I'm going to go over our core crops that are producing those kinds of numbers and some of the crops that produce less. And the point I'm making with this video is not to brag or anything because I think eventually that number is going to be a lot bigger for our farm. But once we expand because eventually we're going to be doing one to one and a half acres of production. But the point I'm making here is that you can grow a lot of food on a small land base and make a living or grow food for your family. And I do offer a gardening course called Gardening 101. The link is in the description where I'm teaching you the similar techniques that I use on this farm to use in your backyard and grow a truckload of food for your family on a couple hundred square feet of land. You know, you don't need a lot of land to do this kind of production. So on every bed that you see behind me, we're trying to get two crops a year in the field. Some of the crops grow so big and bulky that we don't really need to get two crops to make money and produce some amount of food. Like this celery is an example. This celery is going to be almost double the size by the time we harvest it and it'll be worth at least $5 each. So we don't need to get two crops for that. But most of the other crops you see behind me like these carrots, they're the second crop. This is a fall crop. So the technique that I'm talking about is growing really high yield crops and growing multiple crops in the same space if possible. So both of those things combined is how we get to $4,000 a week on a half an acre of production. So let's get into it and highly encourage you to check out that gardening course in the description. It's a game changer. You'll be able to grow $1,200 worth of food in 200 square feet with the techniques I talked about in that course. So check it out and let's get into the video. Okay, so you could probably think a guess about what I'm going to talk about next and that is tomatoes. So tomatoes are one of the most profitable crops that we grow on the farm. And I guess I should actually explain that a little more. It's not exactly about the profit that they bring in, but the yield that they bring in in this small amount of space is incredible. So these are our Granadero paste tomatoes and they are just exploding this year. It's the best crop I've ever had. And we're not just growing paste. We're growing paste, beef steak, heirloom, and cherry tomatoes throughout the farm. This is our second crop right now. The first crop is still producing really well that we planted back in April. This crop we planted late May and they're just exploding right now. We're in full tomato production right now. We're doing 300 to 400 pounds of tomatoes per week. That's a lot and it's the most I've ever done. And that yield is for indeterminate tomatoes. So we're getting that every week and we've been getting about 2 to 250 every week since like 4th of July. And it just exploded once we had the second crop come in. So that's between all four different kinds, but the paste tomatoes are really exploding right now as you can see. And the way we're getting these yields is these are grafted tomatoes. So we've grafted them onto a rootstock back in March and in February for the first crop. So that's a separate variety of tomato that you splice onto the variety you want to produce. And that increases yield a lot if you get the right rootstock. And that's really complicated. I can't explain it in this video. And that's in that farm course that I've talked about in the past. And it's very hard to do. I'm not going to lie. I've screwed it up many times and I've got a pretty good results with it this year. And certain varieties do better, but that increases yields a lot. So that's a big reason we're getting the kind of yields we're getting because there's only about a little over 200 plants in this greenhouse and about 150 in the other one. So it's not a lot of plants if you know about tomato production. But we graft them, we prune the bottom leaves and prune the suckers. So they're all growing up a string. And so that increases yields also in the space that we have. They're in a greenhouse also and then they are on drip irrigation as well. The drip irrigation we have on a timer so it's a completely even watering and we don't have any problems with splitting or anything like that. So it's a pretty complicated process, but it's worth it to get those kinds of numbers because right now we're actually getting $5 a pound for all those tomatoes and $7 a pound for cherries. $6 a pound for heirlooms. They're very valuable in our climate. Nobody can grow them in their garden here because it's still below 50 degrees at night. So very few people can have tomatoes in the western mountains. Again, I'm in Cody, Wyoming for anybody who's new. So it's a very mountainous cold climate. So it's very hard to grow tomatoes here. So they're very valuable. I'm the only guy at a big city market with them so it's pretty easy to get that price. And I just heard that organic tomatoes at the store are $5 a pound anyway so I don't feel bad at all about that price. I used to think that was really expensive, but after doing the work involved with this we're pruning these and maintaining them every week. I have employees managing them. It's a very intense process. So that's how we can get those numbers, but when you get that kind of price it's quite a bit of money. So that's almost $1,000 a week in tomatoes right now, probably more. And it goes up and down, depends on the yield. They ripen differently depending on the weather. There's all sorts of factors in there, but those kinds of numbers are possible with that amount of space. We're only using a quarter or a little less than half of the greenhouse, this whole greenhouse for tomatoes. So we still have room to grow all sorts of other stuff like cucumbers which are the other ridiculously profitable crop that we get great numbers on. We're getting about 200 cucumbers a week right now, and that's actually kind of low for the amount of plants. I'm sure we can get better. And we kind of do this similar technique with tomatoes. We prune the bottom leaves and the suckers with those and grow them up a string with drip tape. Similar fertility, we're doing, we fed these crops every week with alfalfa meal and stuff. That also helps a lot. I've noticed just after this is like the third year I've been doing this, so it's working really, really well. And so that's, all that work gets you those kinds of numbers. And if you have really good employees it doesn't cost that much. You need to do it fast and make sure that those fertilizers aren't that expensive. So it becomes really profitable when you do it that way. But those two crops are bringing in the bulk of that $4,000. It's about $1,500 a week between the two of those. And it's every single week, it's just like clockwork. I don't have to replant another crop, it just keeps coming. So it's a really nice crop. We've been getting those kinds of numbers with tomatoes since the 4th of July. And the other thing about it is it helps sell all the other crops I'm going to talk about. Tomatoes just, when you're the only guy with tomatoes at the market you could sell almost anything you want. So the other crops I'm about to talk about are even more profitable, but they're harder to sell. So when you put them right next to your tomatoes you can really make a lot of money that way. So yeah, I think that's kind of helpful information for people who are kind of getting into this and learning what kind of numbers you can make. But this is literally what we're making right at this minute and I'm sure we can make a lot more in the future. And it's hard. The big caveat with tomatoes is it takes a lot of skill to grow like this. I mean, I screwed up bad. This is the fourth year I've been growing them like this. And it was not even close to those numbers the first three. It's not the little intricacies that I can't explain in this video that you have to learn to get those kinds of numbers. It's not really that easy, especially, you know, it all depends on your climate too. So there's a lot of things. I don't want to make it sound like it's easy to get those numbers. But that's the numbers we're getting right now. Let's move on to the next crops. All right. So next thing I'm going to talk about is probably the biggest moneymaker of all, which is salad greens. And I'm kind of leaving that as a broad category because it kind of cut greens. We grow like a bunch of different kinds of those. We grow salad, over lettuce is the biggest. Arugula is second biggest. We grow tons of both of these. But we also do tons of spinach, minors, lettuce, baby kale, and we also cut salad greens that are bubbled, spun, dried, and bagged. And it all pretty much is the same price. It just depends on, you know, the volume people are buying. But the price changes a little bit in the winter when we're, you know, really the only person with any fresh produce that's a little more expensive. But bottom line is we're doing about 60 to 80 pounds of salad greens a week right now. And lots of other farms do way more numbers than that. But just at the level that we're at in our market, that's what's working. We're selling about 30, 40% of that. No, actually about 50% of that to restaurants. And we're slowly selling more and more at this new market we're at, at full retail price. So we're getting anywhere from $7 to $10 a pound on the greens. Lots more of them are starting to go to the farmers market at $10 a pound. And that's working really, really well. You know, it's taken me a while to get to that level. It's hard to get a top dollar for them when that's all you're selling. But now that we're selling at a bigger market with a lot more people, we can get a better price. And the real key with this is the yields. You know, the price is definitely important. But you know, the more yield you can sell, keyword selling is where you can really make the money there. So, you know, that's providing, you know, $600 to $800 a week basically. And we really want to sell them more and more at the farmers market. But you got to be careful with it because these are the one product that definitely have a shelf life. The Salanova has an incredible shelf life for a cut lettuce. It probably lasts 7 to 10 days. I've had it last two weeks and I probably would still sell it. It's incredible. I don't know why, but it just, when it's growing well, it lasts a really long time. But Arugula is really about a week max, 4 to 7 days. And most of the other greens don't last as long. Spinach lasts a really long time. So you got to make sure you sell it. Because if you cut it and wash it and dry it and it goes bad, you got problems. And having a cold room is a really key detail here. That's what's going to pretty much guarantee that you sell it all. When I used to do this before I had a cold room, it was just so much riskier. So there was a slow market. I lose all, you know, half the crop. So key detail is being able to sell it and having a cold room. Because once, if you have a slow market, you could at least bring it back to the cold room and find another market. But salad greens are a huge part of the business. You know, and you can't, it's hard in my market to sell these by themselves. You got to sell them with some kind of draw in the summertime at least. So those tomatoes are what I'm talking about. That's a huge draw. We're the only people with tomatoes at the market right now. And that's how we're able to sell, you know, 40 pounds of this at full retail price. You know, and this particular Salanova lettuce also is just a spectacular product. It lasts really long time. People love it. It's very versatile. You can put it on sandwiches, restaurants love it. It's easy to harvest. You know, the way we can get really good yields on this, this whole bed, when we cut it, will probably yield 50, 60 pounds. Because it's going to, this isn't really ready yet. This is two weeks away and it will get way bigger. It'll fill out the bed and it'll be completely like an ocean of lettuce. And we'll cut it and then it regrows slightly lower yield, the second cut. But it does grow a second cut. And you'll get at least 80 pounds per bed. That's a lot of money right there. That's, if you do the math on that, it's just say you get $7 a pound. I think that's, oh, it's seven times eight. I'm not, I don't know. I can't remember it off the top of my head. But, you know, that's between like six and eight hundred dollars, you know, in about 60 days. That's really profitable. You know, most crops don't yield that kind of number. So we really try to focus a lot on this. It's a very expensive seed. There's a lot to growing lettuce, but once you get good at growing lettuce, you can grow any kind of lettuce and it works well. So that's a really big part of our business is cut greens. So 60 to 80 pounds is part of that $4,000 number. Let's move on to the next crop. So these are probably the most underrated crop ever. These are pea shoots. And I started growing these two years ago and I just started actually selling them in the summer this year. I normally was just doing it in the winter because I figured they'd be really hard to sell. And they are pretty hard to sell. But in, when you have a really good market and you have a draw crop like tomatoes, you could sell a lot of these. And we also do sunflower shoots and a couple other microgreens. But these yield incredible amounts of shoots per flat. This one flat right here will probably yield two pounds, just about two pounds of pea shoots at $16 a pound I could sell at the market all day. And people really love them after they try them. It's great on a sandwich. It's a great little rabbit food thing to add to the salad department on your booth. And we're selling about eight pounds at the market a week right now. This in sunflower shoots is doing really, really well. So that's a huge money maker. We also sell this to restaurants. The restaurants love to buy it. And a lot of wholesalers are selling pea shoots anyway. And a fancy restaurant is going to be buying them anyway. So your product is going to be ten times better than theirs anyway. Because it's so fresh. It has a great shelf life. It's almost better than salad greens for some reason. I'm finding it lasts like two weeks, no problem. I don't know why. You'll find that every single leaf crop has a different shelf life. Herbs are really weird too. Certain herbs will last forever. Certain ones won't. But shoots are a huge money maker. We're doing eight pounds a week at $16 a pound. So that's a huge part of that $4,000. And we just started really doing well with that about two weeks ago. But it works really well when you play it off salad mix and arugula. You can do a two for nine deal or something where you mix and match. And people will buy one bag of salad mix, one five ounce bag of this. Works great. And it's a very, very good money maker. So you've got to try doing it if you are doing any kind of farming. It's very easy to produce once you learn how. I can't explain how to do it here, but there's lots of videos out there on how to do it. So I highly recommend you try shoots. Okay. So you might be able to guess what our next crop is if you've ever grown them. And that is carrots. I've talked about this in a couple other videos, but we have like, I forgot how many are one, two, three, four, five, six, at least six beds of carrots growing out in the field right now and about eight or so growing in the greenhouses. So that can tell you a little bit of how important carrots are for the farm. We're doing about 150 to 200 bunches of carrots a week. So one of these beds gets harvested every week, at least sometimes two. We have enough labor right now where we can do that. It does take quite a while to harvest carrots. But carrots are just, they're just like a bomb-proof crop because you're always going to sell them. You know, you can either sell them bunched or you break them down and sell them in the one-pound bags and people are going to buy them. So we grow them, a lot of them fresh bunched. That's the best way to make money. But you know, worst case scenario, you break them down after the market and sell them bagged and that's pretty good as well. A lot of what you see right here is our storage crop that we're going to sell in the winter. And so there's a variety that's supposed to last six months or something. So we're going to do like 600 pounds of those and sell them slowly over the winter. You know, I don't want to do too many of that, too much of that because it's pretty hard to harvest 600 pounds in like a day. And we try to do it quick because you want to harvest that before it gets too cold. Otherwise they've turned a little bit crunchy and weird, but they don't store as well. So we'll harvest those sometime in October, probably this year. But carrots are a big backbone of the farm and basically all root crops. But carrots are the most important because a lot of people can grow beets and radishes and stuff in their garden, but very few grow carrots well because it's hard to germinate them. And it's, that's the number one reason, I think. Most people just can't germinate them or they forget to plant them again in July. You know, we plant them basically every month we'll do a big planting four or five beds at a time and do, you know, start that in like March through July. You know, and that's our carrots for the whole year pretty much. I've tried doing a couple of weird plantings in January and that sort of works. But yeah, we do lots and lots of carrots. It's a big backbone of the farm. And so we're doing 150 to 200 bunches. It depends on the size of the carrots, how big of a bunches are, how good the germination was on that bed. And sometimes I'll harvest them before it's going to yield us 200 bunches because I need to flip that bed to some other crop. It doesn't really matter if we wait to get the full yield. But you know, at a minimum of $3 a bunch, that's a lot of money. That's at least $600 a week, more usually. We do this thing where we're doing rainbow carrots and regular carrots and you get two for six at the market and that works really well, but you charge $4 for one. So you're getting basically $3.50 a bunch that way and it works really well because not everybody buys two and all sorts of stuff. So carrots are a big part of it. We do a fair amount of beets, radishes, probably about the same amount in those three crops, beets, radishes and green onions a week. But our yields on those have not been as good as I want them to be. Mostly it's just stuff going wrong. And I don't really try that hard on beets because they don't make that much money. They're a lot harder to sell also. Carrots, I'll sell three to one on beets. You know, people don't get as excited about beets. Radishes have been very good, but they don't grow well in the summer. I can't get them to produce well when flea beetles are going crazy because it's just hot. So I wish I could grow more radishes. I think next year I will be able to. So that's a huge part of that number too. Let's move on to the next crop. Alright, so herbs in general are a huge part of our business now. Slowly built that into the business because it is hard to sell them on their own. But we're selling a lot to restaurants right now and a lot at the farmers market. So right now we're only doing parsley, cilantro, and dill. And they're all kind of growing roughly the same and bunched the same, priced the same. We're doing about $3 a bunch for roughly a 4-ounce bunch. But sometimes it's 6 ounces or 8 ounces depending on what's going on. But these are really profitable crops. I mean, this one bit of parsley will probably bring in $800. And that's because we're going to harvest it at least twice. And there's going to be probably 300 and something bunches coming out of here. And it might be a little less than 800 actually because this one won't go as long. But that first bed we had did at least $1,000 because we harvested it about three times. Parsley comes back again and again and again. And it's really valuable at a market like mine because if you're the only guy with it, people want that. And if it's really fresh, they get a big bunch that looks way better than the old stuff at the store. It's a huge, huge money maker. You just got to have a cold room and be able to store it. And this one has a great shelf life. Cilantro and dill, which is what you see behind me. We do a lot of that as well. That's probably even more profitable. But not quite because you have to plant that so much more often. Parsley you plant it once and just keeps going. But the cilantro and dill will bolt. But we're getting at least two crops out of each bed. And it's just a truckload. We're selling a lot of those to restaurants. And the cilantro is just going like hotcakes at the market because people are making salsa with the tomatoes. So we're doing 150 to 200 bunches of herbs per week right now between the three of those crops. Between two to three dollars a bunch depending on who's buying it. So that's a huge part of that number. I anticipate we'll be doing at least 500 bunches a week soon. Not this year, but next year. Because the market is just going to keep as our production of things like tomatoes and those draw crops increase and our reputation increases. We'll just sell more. We'll sell more to restaurants. We're going to also start doing perennial herbs like oregano, rosemary, stuff like that. You can charge more for those. And they all herbs grow back. So you get at least two cuts per bed. And it's not a super sexy crop. But once you get people into it, they're going to come back to your booth just to buy those. I have a lot of Eastern European customers that are coming back just to buy dill. And our dill looks so much better than most dill at the market because it doesn't go to seed. It's always fresh. We plant it all the time to keep it that way. But it's worth it because of the amount of production you can get and yield. So really big part of our business. That's five to six hundred dollars a week just in those crops. And we did terrible with basil this year. Basil is another huge money maker, but I just didn't do a very good job of growing the plants this year. So they're really behind and not growing well. But basil is even more money. So herbs are just a big, big part of making a lot of money in a small space. So let's move on to the next crops. Okay, last but definitely not least is what I'm calling miscellaneous crops, which is like a lot of different crops. But they all, we kind of sell them all the same. They're all about like three to four dollars per unit. And we're doing 250 to 300 of those units per week on between all the different stuff. It depends on the week. So like cabbage was really hot in the last couple of weeks. We're almost done with that. That was three dollars a unit. We're doing 50, 60 heads of those a week. Head lettuce, 50, 60 heads of those a week. Celery, that's just going to start coming on in a couple of weeks. We're actually doing bunch celery right now. We just started that. I just did a hundred bunches of those today. And those are selling at four dollars a bunch. Celery is a very profitable crop because nobody grows it and it's delicious, tastes so much better than the store. Organic celery right now is four dollars a pound or something right now at the store. So it's like exactly the same as the store, but white year's better. Celery is a really good one. It takes forever to grow, but once you have it and people have tried it, it's a big money maker because you could charge a lot for it. People who are juicing are going to buy a truckload of it because it's actually really cheap for juice because it's like 100% juice. And the juice quality is off the charts. So celery is one of my favorites. We sell it. We're trying it as a head full head and bunched this year. The bunching you can actually pick. We're going to get at least two crops out of that batch. If you plant it early enough, you can get three. You just take the outer stems and then it regrows from the center. Big, big money maker. So between all of those, it's like a thousand dollars a week in those miscellaneous crops. And that means that's including kale, chard, stuff like that. So we try to incorporate a lot of those to add variety to the table. We're growing 25 different crops right now. I don't know if that's going to change a whole lot in the future. We might go up to 40, maybe a maximum, but there's just a, I don't want to do too much variety because it gets hard. Each crop is definitely a skill set in growing. I'd say actually throughout the year, we do probably grow about 40 different crops. But right now it's about 25 that we're actually harvesting. That's including stuff like summer squash and zucchini. All those crops add up to money at your market table. And so between all of the crops I've talked about in this video, that's where we're getting the average of $4,000 a week. And last week was almost five. This week will be probably close to five and then it'll start to go down again. So it really depends on what's going on. We're going to harvest shallots soon and that's going to be, that'll make it like 6,000. But that's something we sell throughout the year. And when I say 4,000 a week, it doesn't necessarily mean we're selling that every week. Although right now we pretty much are. Some of it we store and sell later. Like carrots bags will sell later. If we have a bumper crop, we could stretch that a little bit because we have a cold room. Stuff like cabbage also, if I needed to harvest a whole bed at once, I could sell that months later if I wanted to. Celery, I could probably sell a month later. It lasts forever. Salad greens, we got to sell that pretty much that week. But kale even, you can stretch that for a while. So we have sold almost everything we've grown this year. There's a couple pounds of greens that we didn't sell at the very beginning before the markets really picked up. But we're selling everything right now. So we're producing $4,000 a week. Almost everything we sell is in about a $3 portion. That's kind of standard farmers market thing. The tomatoes, there's more just because if we didn't do that, we would sell out in an hour and then everything else would stop selling. You'll notice if you're in that position that if you sell out of tomatoes in two hours, the last two hours, your sales drop because the draw to your boost stops. So we are trying to sell it slow throughout that whole period to sell out of the salad greens and stuff. And it's working really, really well. Right now, I don't think we have any problem. We have so many. We'll start freezing them and selling them in the winter. But even with tomatoes, if you don't sell them, you freeze them and you could sell them $4 a pound in the winter. And people use them in stews and stuff and it works great. So, you know, that $4,000 a week is just a rough average. And it depends. I mean, we could really bump that up. If we had everything going perfectly like I had planned, it might have been five. But, you know, in farming, a lot of things go wrong. I'm still a pretty young farm and I'm a young farmer. I'm still learning a lot, so I still make mistakes and things go wrong. So that's like, you know, a real nice solid number for me. I'm very happy with that this year, given the size of the farm. And again, we're a half an acre farm. I think we have a total of about 80, 50-foot beds. That's not that much. 50-foot means 50 feet long, 2.5 feet wide. So this bed right here is a 50-foot bed of celery. That's a 50-foot bed of lettuce. So we're doing that. And some of those, you know, the tomatoes is like... I did a video a long time ago, earlier this year, about how much money you can make in a greenhouse. And I talked about some of the numbers you can make on one bed of tomatoes. One bed of tomatoes this year for us is about $2,000 in revenue, at least. And it depends on, you know, how early it is and stuff. But those numbers are just numbers. You know, it depends on how successful you are, the weather, all sorts of stuff. But baseline numbers, that's what you can expect if you're good. And that's a key detail, you know. I saw some of these numbers a long time ago, and I got really excited my first year, and I expected to get them, and I didn't. Like, things just don't work well until you build your skill set as a grower. And I'm still doing that myself. So there's a lot of factors involved. And labor is another factor, too. You've got to have really good labor to make all these numbers happen easily, at least, and not break your back. And we do this year, I'm very fortunate that we do. But this is just kind of a glimpse of what is possible, because, again, we're only doing a half an acre of production. I think it's pretty incredible to be able to bring in that kind of revenue on a half an acre, because lots of places in the world have a half an acre to grow on. It's not very much land, especially with the price of land going up now. I just wanted to put this video out there, because when I first started, I looked for these kinds of numbers, like the yields that a farm was getting, because it helps you kind of plan a potential of your business. I think it's helpful to know what other farms are accomplishing, so you know what's possible, at least. And there's a lot of factors to yields, and I'm sure my yields can be a lot better. I want to get better at growing more food on a small space every single year, in the same bed. And that's how you can really make money with this. And I know that as my skills improve, that will be possible. But this is what I'm accomplishing right now, and hopefully this inspires somebody out there to think twice about starting a farm or something. So, hope you enjoyed that, and I will see you in the next one.

segments.text: So I've recently come out with a couple videos talking about how we're getting $4,000 a week in production on this vegetable farm.
And in this video I want to explain a little bit about our yields that we're harvesting every week to get to that $4,000.
I think that'll kind of clear up any confusion you get from that because just the number could mean a lot of different things.
But I want to really explain how much food we're really producing on a half an acre of land, which is a tiny amount of land.
You know, you can do a half an acre of production in Chicago, downtown, in the city of Chicago.
You know, that's not a lot of land. So I'm going to go over that today.
I'm going to go over our core crops that are producing those kinds of numbers and some of the crops that produce less.
And the point I'm making with this video is not to brag or anything because I think eventually that number is going to be a lot bigger for our farm.
But once we expand because eventually we're going to be doing one to one and a half acres of production.
But the point I'm making here is that you can grow a lot of food on a small land base and make a living or grow food for your family.
And I do offer a gardening course called Gardening 101.

The link is in the description where I'm teaching you the similar techniques that I use on this farm to use in your backyard and grow a truckload of food for your family on a couple hundred square feet of land.
You know, you don't need a lot of land to do this kind of production.
So on every bed that you see behind me, we're trying to get two crops a year in the field.
Some of the crops grow so big and bulky that we don't really need to get two crops to make money and produce some amount of food.
Like this celery is an example.
This celery is going to be almost double the size by the time we harvest it and it'll be worth at least $5 each.
So we don't need to get two crops for that.
But most of the other crops you see behind me like these carrots, they're the second crop.
This is a fall crop.
So the technique that I'm talking about is growing really high yield crops and growing multiple crops in the same space if possible.
So both of those things combined is how we get to $4,000 a week on a half an acre of production.
So let's get into it and highly encourage you to check out that gardening course in the description.
It's a game changer.
You'll be able to grow $1,200 worth of food in 200 square feet with the techniques I talked about in that course.
So check it out and let's get into the video.
Okay, so you could probably think a guess about what I'm going to talk about next and that is tomatoes.
So tomatoes are one of the most profitable crops that we grow on the farm.
And I guess I should actually explain that a little more.
It's not exactly about the profit that they bring in, but the yield that they bring in in this small amount of space is incredible.
So these are our Granadero paste tomatoes and they are just exploding this year.
It's the best crop I've ever had.
And we're not just growing paste.
We're growing paste, beef steak, heirloom, and cherry tomatoes throughout the farm.
This is our second crop right now.
The first crop is still producing really well that we planted back in April.
This crop we planted late May and they're just exploding right now.
We're in full tomato production right now.
We're doing 300 to 400 pounds of tomatoes per week.
That's a lot and it's the most I've ever done.
And that yield is for indeterminate tomatoes.
So we're getting that every week and we've been getting about 2 to 250 every week since like 4th of July.
And it just exploded once we had the second crop come in.
So that's between all four different kinds, but the paste tomatoes are really exploding right now as you can see.
And the way we're getting these yields is these are grafted tomatoes.
So we've grafted them onto a rootstock back in March and in February for the first crop.
So that's a separate variety of tomato that you splice onto the variety you want to produce.
And that increases yield a lot if you get the right rootstock.
And that's really complicated. I can't explain it in this video.
And that's in that farm course that I've talked about in the past.
And it's very hard to do. I'm not going to lie.
I've screwed it up many times and I've got a pretty good results with it this year.
And certain varieties do better, but that increases yields a lot.
So that's a big reason we're getting the kind of yields we're getting because there's only about
a little over 200 plants in this greenhouse and about 150 in the other one.
So it's not a lot of plants if you know about tomato production.
But we graft them, we prune the bottom leaves and prune the suckers.
So they're all growing up a string.
And so that increases yields also in the space that we have.
They're in a greenhouse also and then they are on drip irrigation as well.
The drip irrigation we have on a timer so it's a completely even watering
and we don't have any problems with splitting or anything like that.
So it's a pretty complicated process, but it's worth it to get those kinds of numbers
because right now we're actually getting $5 a pound for all those tomatoes
and $7 a pound for cherries. $6 a pound for heirlooms.
They're very valuable in our climate. Nobody can grow them in their garden here
because it's still below 50 degrees at night.
So very few people can have tomatoes in the western mountains.
Again, I'm in Cody, Wyoming for anybody who's new.
So it's a very mountainous cold climate. So it's very hard to grow tomatoes here.
So they're very valuable. I'm the only guy at a big city market with them
so it's pretty easy to get that price.
And I just heard that organic tomatoes at the store are $5 a pound anyway
so I don't feel bad at all about that price.
I used to think that was really expensive, but after doing the work involved with this
we're pruning these and maintaining them every week.
I have employees managing them. It's a very intense process.
So that's how we can get those numbers, but when you get that kind of price
it's quite a bit of money. So that's almost $1,000 a week in tomatoes right now, probably more.
And it goes up and down, depends on the yield.
They ripen differently depending on the weather.
There's all sorts of factors in there, but those kinds of numbers are possible with that amount of space.
We're only using a quarter or a little less than half of the greenhouse,
this whole greenhouse for tomatoes.
So we still have room to grow all sorts of other stuff like cucumbers
which are the other ridiculously profitable crop that we get great numbers on.
We're getting about 200 cucumbers a week right now, and that's actually kind of low for the amount of plants.
I'm sure we can get better.
And we kind of do this similar technique with tomatoes.
We prune the bottom leaves and the suckers with those and grow them up a string with drip tape.
Similar fertility, we're doing, we fed these crops every week with alfalfa meal and stuff.
That also helps a lot.
I've noticed just after this is like the third year I've been doing this, so it's working really, really well.
And so that's, all that work gets you those kinds of numbers.
And if you have really good employees it doesn't cost that much.
You need to do it fast and make sure that those fertilizers aren't that expensive.
So it becomes really profitable when you do it that way.
But those two crops are bringing in the bulk of that $4,000.
It's about $1,500 a week between the two of those.
And it's every single week, it's just like clockwork.
I don't have to replant another crop, it just keeps coming.
So it's a really nice crop.
We've been getting those kinds of numbers with tomatoes since the 4th of July.
And the other thing about it is it helps sell all the other crops I'm going to talk about.
Tomatoes just, when you're the only guy with tomatoes at the market you could sell almost anything you want.
So the other crops I'm about to talk about are even more profitable, but they're harder to sell.
So when you put them right next to your tomatoes you can really make a lot of money that way.
So yeah, I think that's kind of helpful information for people who are kind of getting into this
and learning what kind of numbers you can make.
But this is literally what we're making right at this minute
and I'm sure we can make a lot more in the future.
And it's hard. The big caveat with tomatoes is it takes a lot of skill to grow like this.
I mean, I screwed up bad.
This is the fourth year I've been growing them like this.
And it was not even close to those numbers the first three.
It's not the little intricacies that I can't explain in this video that you have to learn
to get those kinds of numbers.
It's not really that easy, especially, you know, it all depends on your climate too.
So there's a lot of things.
I don't want to make it sound like it's easy to get those numbers.
But that's the numbers we're getting right now.
Let's move on to the next crops.
All right. So next thing I'm going to talk about is probably the biggest moneymaker of all,
which is salad greens.
And I'm kind of leaving that as a broad category because it kind of cut greens.
We grow like a bunch of different kinds of those.
We grow salad, over lettuce is the biggest.
Arugula is second biggest. We grow tons of both of these.
But we also do tons of spinach, minors, lettuce, baby kale,
and we also cut salad greens that are bubbled, spun, dried, and bagged.
And it all pretty much is the same price.
It just depends on, you know, the volume people are buying.
But the price changes a little bit in the winter when we're, you know,
really the only person with any fresh produce that's a little more expensive.
But bottom line is we're doing about 60 to 80 pounds of salad greens a week right now.
And lots of other farms do way more numbers than that.
But just at the level that we're at in our market, that's what's working.
We're selling about 30, 40% of that.
No, actually about 50% of that to restaurants.
And we're slowly selling more and more at this new market we're at,
at full retail price.
So we're getting anywhere from $7 to $10 a pound on the greens.
Lots more of them are starting to go to the farmers market at $10 a pound.
And that's working really, really well.
You know, it's taken me a while to get to that level.
It's hard to get a top dollar for them when that's all you're selling.
But now that we're selling at a bigger market with a lot more people,
we can get a better price.
And the real key with this is the yields.
You know, the price is definitely important.
But you know, the more yield you can sell,
keyword selling is where you can really make the money there.
So, you know, that's providing, you know, $600 to $800 a week basically.
And we really want to sell them more and more at the farmers market.
But you got to be careful with it because these are the one product
that definitely have a shelf life.
The Salanova has an incredible shelf life for a cut lettuce.
It probably lasts 7 to 10 days.
I've had it last two weeks and I probably would still sell it.
It's incredible.
I don't know why, but it just, when it's growing well, it lasts a really long time.
But Arugula is really about a week max, 4 to 7 days.
And most of the other greens don't last as long.
Spinach lasts a really long time.
So you got to make sure you sell it.
Because if you cut it and wash it and dry it and it goes bad, you got problems.
And having a cold room is a really key detail here.
That's what's going to pretty much guarantee that you sell it all.
When I used to do this before I had a cold room, it was just so much riskier.
So there was a slow market.
I lose all, you know, half the crop.
So key detail is being able to sell it and having a cold room.
Because once, if you have a slow market,
you could at least bring it back to the cold room and find another market.
But salad greens are a huge part of the business.
You know, and you can't, it's hard in my market to sell these by themselves.
You got to sell them with some kind of draw in the summertime at least.
So those tomatoes are what I'm talking about.
That's a huge draw.
We're the only people with tomatoes at the market right now.
And that's how we're able to sell, you know, 40 pounds of this at full retail price.
You know, and this particular Salanova lettuce also is just a spectacular product.
It lasts really long time.
People love it.
It's very versatile.
You can put it on sandwiches, restaurants love it.
It's easy to harvest.
You know, the way we can get really good yields on this,
this whole bed, when we cut it, will probably yield 50, 60 pounds.
Because it's going to, this isn't really ready yet.
This is two weeks away and it will get way bigger.
It'll fill out the bed and it'll be completely like an ocean of lettuce.
And we'll cut it and then it regrows slightly lower yield, the second cut.
But it does grow a second cut.
And you'll get at least 80 pounds per bed.
That's a lot of money right there.
That's, if you do the math on that, it's just say you get $7 a pound.
I think that's, oh, it's seven times eight.
I'm not, I don't know.
I can't remember it off the top of my head.
But, you know, that's between like six and eight hundred dollars, you know,
in about 60 days.
That's really profitable.
You know, most crops don't yield that kind of number.
So we really try to focus a lot on this.
It's a very expensive seed.
There's a lot to growing lettuce, but once you get good at growing lettuce,
you can grow any kind of lettuce and it works well.
So that's a really big part of our business is cut greens.
So 60 to 80 pounds is part of that $4,000 number.
Let's move on to the next crop.
So these are probably the most underrated crop ever.
These are pea shoots.
And I started growing these two years ago and I just started actually selling them
in the summer this year.
I normally was just doing it in the winter because I figured they'd be really hard to sell.
And they are pretty hard to sell.
But in, when you have a really good market and you have a draw crop like tomatoes,
you could sell a lot of these.
And we also do sunflower shoots and a couple other microgreens.
But these yield incredible amounts of shoots per flat.
This one flat right here will probably yield two pounds,
just about two pounds of pea shoots at $16 a pound I could sell at the market all day.
And people really love them after they try them.
It's great on a sandwich.
It's a great little rabbit food thing to add to the salad department on your booth.
And we're selling about eight pounds at the market a week right now.
This in sunflower shoots is doing really, really well.
So that's a huge money maker.
We also sell this to restaurants.
The restaurants love to buy it.
And a lot of wholesalers are selling pea shoots anyway.
And a fancy restaurant is going to be buying them anyway.
So your product is going to be ten times better than theirs anyway.
Because it's so fresh.
It has a great shelf life.
It's almost better than salad greens for some reason.
I'm finding it lasts like two weeks, no problem.
I don't know why.
You'll find that every single leaf crop has a different shelf life.
Herbs are really weird too.
Certain herbs will last forever.
Certain ones won't.
But shoots are a huge money maker.
We're doing eight pounds a week at $16 a pound.
So that's a huge part of that $4,000.
And we just started really doing well with that about two weeks ago.
But it works really well when you play it off salad mix and arugula.
You can do a two for nine deal or something where you mix and match.
And people will buy one bag of salad mix, one five ounce bag of this.
Works great.
And it's a very, very good money maker.
So you've got to try doing it if you are doing any kind of farming.
It's very easy to produce once you learn how.
I can't explain how to do it here, but there's lots of videos out there on how to do it.
So I highly recommend you try shoots.

So you might be able to guess what our next crop is if you've ever grown them.
And that is carrots.

I forgot how many are one, two, three, four, five, six,
at least six beds of carrots growing out in the field right now and about
eight or so growing in the greenhouses.
So that can tell you a little bit of how important carrots are for the farm.
We're doing about 150 to 200 bunches of carrots a week.
So one of these beds gets harvested every week, at least sometimes two.
We have enough labor right now where we can do that.
It does take quite a while to harvest carrots.
But carrots are just, they're just like a bomb-proof crop
because you're always going to sell them.
You know, you can either sell them bunched or you break them down
and sell them in the one-pound bags and people are going to buy them.
So we grow them, a lot of them fresh bunched.
That's the best way to make money.
But you know, worst case scenario, you break them down after the market
and sell them bagged and that's pretty good as well.
A lot of what you see right here is our storage crop that we're going to sell in the winter.
And so there's a variety that's supposed to last six months or something.
So we're going to do like 600 pounds of those and sell them slowly over the winter.
You know, I don't want to do too many of that, too much of that
because it's pretty hard to harvest 600 pounds in like a day.
And we try to do it quick because you want to harvest that before it gets too cold.
Otherwise they've turned a little bit crunchy and weird, but they don't store as well.
So we'll harvest those sometime in October, probably this year.
But carrots are a big backbone of the farm and basically all root crops.
But carrots are the most important because a lot of people can grow beets
and radishes and stuff in their garden, but very few grow carrots well
because it's hard to germinate them.
And it's, that's the number one reason, I think.
Most people just can't germinate them or they forget to plant them again in July.
You know, we plant them basically every month we'll do a big planting
four or five beds at a time and do, you know, start that in like March through July.
You know, and that's our carrots for the whole year pretty much.
I've tried doing a couple of weird plantings in January and that sort of works.
But yeah, we do lots and lots of carrots.
It's a big backbone of the farm.
And so we're doing 150 to 200 bunches.
It depends on the size of the carrots, how big of a bunches are,
how good the germination was on that bed.
And sometimes I'll harvest them before it's going to yield us 200 bunches
because I need to flip that bed to some other crop.
It doesn't really matter if we wait to get the full yield.
But you know, at a minimum of $3 a bunch, that's a lot of money.
That's at least $600 a week, more usually.
We do this thing where we're doing rainbow carrots and regular carrots
and you get two for six at the market and that works really well,
but you charge $4 for one.
So you're getting basically $3.50 a bunch that way and it works really well
because not everybody buys two and all sorts of stuff.
So carrots are a big part of it.
We do a fair amount of beets, radishes, probably about the same amount
in those three crops, beets, radishes and green onions a week.
But our yields on those have not been as good as I want them to be.
Mostly it's just stuff going wrong.
And I don't really try that hard on beets because they don't make that much money.
They're a lot harder to sell also.
Carrots, I'll sell three to one on beets.
You know, people don't get as excited about beets.
Radishes have been very good, but they don't grow well in the summer.
I can't get them to produce well when flea beetles are going crazy
because it's just hot.
So I wish I could grow more radishes.
I think next year I will be able to.
So that's a huge part of that number too.
Let's move on to the next crop.
Alright, so herbs in general are a huge part of our business now.
Slowly built that into the business because it is hard to sell them on their own.
But we're selling a lot to restaurants right now and a lot at the farmers market.
So right now we're only doing parsley, cilantro, and dill.
And they're all kind of growing roughly the same and bunched the same, priced the same.
We're doing about $3 a bunch for roughly a 4-ounce bunch.
But sometimes it's 6 ounces or 8 ounces depending on what's going on.
But these are really profitable crops.
I mean, this one bit of parsley will probably bring in $800.
And that's because we're going to harvest it at least twice.
And there's going to be probably 300 and something bunches coming out of here.
And it might be a little less than 800 actually because this one won't go as long.
But that first bed we had did at least $1,000 because we harvested it about three times.
Parsley comes back again and again and again.
And it's really valuable at a market like mine because if you're the only guy with it, people want that.
And if it's really fresh, they get a big bunch that looks way better than the old stuff at the store.
It's a huge, huge money maker.
You just got to have a cold room and be able to store it.
And this one has a great shelf life.
Cilantro and dill, which is what you see behind me.
We do a lot of that as well.
That's probably even more profitable.
But not quite because you have to plant that so much more often.
Parsley you plant it once and just keeps going.
But the cilantro and dill will bolt.
But we're getting at least two crops out of each bed.
And it's just a truckload.
We're selling a lot of those to restaurants.
And the cilantro is just going like hotcakes at the market because people are making salsa with the tomatoes.
So we're doing 150 to 200 bunches of herbs per week right now between the three of those crops.
Between two to three dollars a bunch depending on who's buying it.
So that's a huge part of that number.
I anticipate we'll be doing at least 500 bunches a week soon.
Not this year, but next year.
Because the market is just going to keep as our production of things like tomatoes and those draw crops increase and our reputation increases.
We'll just sell more. We'll sell more to restaurants.
We're going to also start doing perennial herbs like oregano, rosemary, stuff like that.
You can charge more for those.
And they all herbs grow back.
So you get at least two cuts per bed.
And it's not a super sexy crop.
But once you get people into it, they're going to come back to your booth just to buy those.
I have a lot of Eastern European customers that are coming back just to buy dill.
And our dill looks so much better than most dill at the market because it doesn't go to seed.
It's always fresh.
We plant it all the time to keep it that way.
But it's worth it because of the amount of production you can get and yield.
So really big part of our business.
That's five to six hundred dollars a week just in those crops.
And we did terrible with basil this year.
Basil is another huge money maker, but I just didn't do a very good job of growing the plants this year.

But basil is even more money.
So herbs are just a big, big part of making a lot of money in a small space.
So let's move on to the next crops.
Okay, last but definitely not least is what I'm calling miscellaneous crops, which is like a lot of different crops.
But they all, we kind of sell them all the same.
They're all about like three to four dollars per unit.
And we're doing 250 to 300 of those units per week on between all the different stuff.
It depends on the week.
So like cabbage was really hot in the last couple of weeks.
We're almost done with that.
That was three dollars a unit.
We're doing 50, 60 heads of those a week.
Head lettuce, 50, 60 heads of those a week.
Celery, that's just going to start coming on in a couple of weeks.
We're actually doing bunch celery right now.
We just started that.
I just did a hundred bunches of those today.
And those are selling at four dollars a bunch.
Celery is a very profitable crop because nobody grows it and it's delicious, tastes so much better than the store.
Organic celery right now is four dollars a pound or something right now at the store.
So it's like exactly the same as the store, but white year's better.
Celery is a really good one.
It takes forever to grow, but once you have it and people have tried it, it's a big money maker because you could charge a lot for it.
People who are juicing are going to buy a truckload of it because it's actually really cheap for juice because it's like 100% juice.
And the juice quality is off the charts.
So celery is one of my favorites.
We sell it.
We're trying it as a head full head and bunched this year.
The bunching you can actually pick.
We're going to get at least two crops out of that batch.
If you plant it early enough, you can get three.
You just take the outer stems and then it regrows from the center.
Big, big money maker.
So between all of those, it's like a thousand dollars a week in those miscellaneous crops.
And that means that's including kale, chard, stuff like that.
So we try to incorporate a lot of those to add variety to the table.
We're growing 25 different crops right now.
I don't know if that's going to change a whole lot in the future.
We might go up to 40, maybe a maximum, but there's just a, I don't want to do too much variety because it gets hard.
Each crop is definitely a skill set in growing.
I'd say actually throughout the year, we do probably grow about 40 different crops.
But right now it's about 25 that we're actually harvesting.
That's including stuff like summer squash and zucchini.
All those crops add up to money at your market table.
And so between all of the crops I've talked about in this video, that's where we're getting the average of $4,000 a week.
And last week was almost five.
This week will be probably close to five and then it'll start to go down again.
So it really depends on what's going on.
We're going to harvest shallots soon and that's going to be, that'll make it like 6,000.
But that's something we sell throughout the year.
And when I say 4,000 a week, it doesn't necessarily mean we're selling that every week.
Although right now we pretty much are.
Some of it we store and sell later.
Like carrots bags will sell later.
If we have a bumper crop, we could stretch that a little bit because we have a cold room.
Stuff like cabbage also, if I needed to harvest a whole bed at once, I could sell that months later if I wanted to.
Celery, I could probably sell a month later.
It lasts forever.
Salad greens, we got to sell that pretty much that week.
But kale even, you can stretch that for a while.
So we have sold almost everything we've grown this year.
There's a couple pounds of greens that we didn't sell at the very beginning before the markets really picked up.
But we're selling everything right now.
So we're producing $4,000 a week.
Almost everything we sell is in about a $3 portion.
That's kind of standard farmers market thing.
The tomatoes, there's more just because if we didn't do that, we would sell out in an hour and then everything else would stop selling.
You'll notice if you're in that position that if you sell out of tomatoes in two hours, the last two hours, your sales drop because the draw to your boost stops.
So we are trying to sell it slow throughout that whole period to sell out of the salad greens and stuff.
And it's working really, really well.
Right now, I don't think we have any problem.
We have so many.
We'll start freezing them and selling them in the winter.
But even with tomatoes, if you don't sell them, you freeze them and you could sell them $4 a pound in the winter.

And it depends.

So that's like, you know, a real nice solid number for me.
I'm very happy with that this year, given the size of the farm.
And again, we're a half an acre farm.
I think we have a total of about 80, 50-foot beds.
